mxCell.value: Nice to meet you!

Welcome [[user_first_name]] to MyBudgetCoach! MyBudgetCoach is a unique budgeting software that comes along with a virtual avatar. You selected, me, Nick Smith, as your personal coach. I look forward to helping you start a new phase of your journey to financial wellness!
Before we begin the set-up process, I just want to let you know about some aspects of MyBudgetCoach.
Great! If I want to pause along the way, it will save my progress.

As your virtual coach, I will be available whenever you are. You can complete the set-up steps all at once, or you can complete them over time. Please move at your pace, and whenever you are ready for the next step of our work together, I will be here to help you out.

Thanks for your response!

We will start off with the following steps for the Account Set-Up stage. 
  1. Renaming Budget
  2. Adding Checking Account
  3. Overview of Account screen
  4. Adding a transaction
Let's get started!
Thanks for the insight!
Ask Away
To personalize your experience setting up MyBudgetCoach, I will ask you questions along the way. These questions will shift my coaching approach so I am tailoring my advice based on your responses.

My current budgeting system isn't bringing me closer to my financial wellness goals
sign_up_reason = not_closer

I haven't created a routine budget process and am looking to get started
sign_up_reason = new_budget
What brought you to sign up for MyBudgetCoach?
I will keep that in mind

You can set-up multiple budgets in your MyBudgetCoach account. An example for when a new budget can be helpful is when you have a big life event, such as a change in job, and want to start 'fresh' with your new financial reality.
I renamed my Budget

MyBudgetCoach allows you to name each budget. I recommend to name the Budget something specific, and end with "..._MonthYear" that you start the budget. This will help you remember which Budget was used for which time period.
Got it, just main checking account for now.

<<Accounts>>

In your early days of using MyBudgetCoach, I recommend adding just your checking account, and leaving out any savings accounts.
I am making progress!

<<Accounts>>

So far, you have completed steps 1 and 2 of the Account Set-Up stage.  
  1. Renaming Budget
  2. Adding Checking Account
  3. Overview of Account screen
  4. Adding a transaction
We will now work through the features of the Account screen.

<<Accounts>>

Starting at the top of the screen, the account name is at the top. This can be a helpful reminder if you aren't sure which account you are working in.
This seems rare; good to know when it comes up!

<<Accounts>>

The arrows to the right of the Search Bar are an option to condense or expand 'split transactions'. Split transactions are when you have a single transaction split between multiple categories.
Hope this won't happen often!
I'm ready!

<<Accounts>>

To verify your understanding of the account screen, I will now walk you through adding two test transactions to the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Please select the '+ Add New' option under the account balance to add a new transaction and select today's date.
I added the payee

<<Accounts>>

For the Payee, let's enter 'Grocery Store.' Since this is a new Payee, select + Create Payee.

<<Accounts>>

For the Notes, let's leave blank for now.
I selected Food for the category

<<Accounts>>

For the Category, select 'Food'. You can type 'F' and watch the available categories filter down accordingly.

<<Accounts>>

Let's assume an outflow of 50 for groceries.

<<Accounts>>

KNOWLEDGE CHECK

Should the 50 be entered
in the 'Payment' or 
'Deposit' column?
I added 50 in the payment column

<<Accounts>>

Correct! Since this is an outflow for the checking account, this purchase is entered into the Payment column. Let's do that now.

<<Accounts>>

Actually, this transaction is entered as a Payment. A Deposit is income coming into your checking account. For example, your paycheck would be a Deposit. Any outflow for purchases or paying bills would be entered as Payment. Let's do that now.
I added my first transaction!

<<Accounts>>

To add the transaction, select the 'Add' button.

<<Accounts>>

Notice that when you add a new transaction, the system defaults the checkmark symbol to a non-filled color which means the transaction is not yet cleared.

<<Accounts>>

For this example, the transaction 
happened earlier in the day, so please select the checkmark to turn it green and 'Clear' the transaction.
I added my paycheck!

<<Accounts>>

Let's now add a transaction for an inflow. For the Payee enter 'Employer,' select a Category of Income, enter 500 in the Deposit field, and select 'Add.'
I see that

<<Accounts>>

Now that you have added two transactions, please take note that the payment to the grocery store has been cleared, but the income has not been cleared.
Ok; I am looking at the two numbers

<<Accounts>>

Please select the Account Balance to view the Cleared and Uncleared total.

<<Accounts>>

Great job adding your  account! Do you feel the momentum building towards achieving your goals!?

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank now so you can gather your current balance of your checking account.
I have added my checking account
Ok; I am logged in

<<Accounts>>

Under the account name is the balance of the account you are viewing. 

You can select the balance, and that expands more details with an amount for uncleared and cleared totals.
Tell me more...

<<Accounts>>

Under the balance is a series of options which makes changes to the transactions table.

<<Accounts>>

Import: This option allows you to upload a csv file created from exporting transactions from your online bank account. Select the 'Transaction Import Options' conversation under 'Manage Coach' to learn more.
I could see using this often

<<Accounts>>

Add New: Select this when you want to manually add a transaction.
Got it; Undo and Redo apply to both Accounts and Budget.

<<Accounts>>

Filter: This allows you to view transactions based on certain requirements. Please select Filter and review the various fields available.
Oh good, a robust search!

<<Accounts>>

Shifting focus now to the right side of the screen, there is the Search Bar. As you start typing, the system dynamically filters down the transactions based on payee, category, or transaction amounts based on the text entered.
Tell me more...

<<Accounts>>

To the right of that are three horizontal dots. This section has sub-selections. 

Let me give a quick overview of each of these options.
I should turn this on now!

<<Accounts>>

Show Running Balance: This is an additional column that shows the balance after each transaction. This is very helpful during reconciliation.

<<Accounts>>

Hide cleared checkboxes: This removes the column showing the cleared (green) or uncleared (grey) checkbox.

<<Accounts>>

Export: You can download transactions as a csv file.
I should do each time I log in? You got it!

<<Accounts>>

Reconcile: This is a very important feature. Reconciliation is the process to verify the account balance and transactions in MyBudgetCoach match your bank account.

<<Accounts>>

Link account: This option allows the user to link MyBudgetCoach to their bank to automate adding transactions. Select the 'Transaction Import Options' conversation under 'Manage Coach' to learn more.
I like storing my data
Expert? Not just yet, but I am getting there!

<<Accounts>>

Alright! That completes the overview of the account screen. Are you starting to feel like a MyBudgetCoach expert!?

<<Accounts>>

Please note, any income received, including returns or rebates, should all be entered with a Category as 'Income.'

If at any time you reach a point where you would like a one-on-one coaching session with me, please select the link to the left and select a time that works for you. Please note, one-on-one coaching has an additional hourly fee, in addition to your MyBudgetCoach subscription.
Tell me more
Thanks for the tip!
Select your Budget Name in the top left and select 'Rename budget' to update the name.

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account". Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Checking' and then enter the current balance of that account

<<Accounts>>

Please select '+ Add account' in the left side menu bar.
Yup! Good call Coach

<<Accounts>>

Before we move to the next step, let's delete those two hypothetical transactions you added.

<<Accounts>>

Please select each of the two transactions by hovering over the date and then selecting the box to the left of the date. Then select the link named '2 transactions' to the right of the search bar and choose Delete.
I have cleared the Income transaction

<<Accounts>>

Notice that the Uncleared total is 500.

Please select the grey check mark to make it green to clear the transaction.
That makes sense

<<Accounts>>

The Cleared total now matches the account balance and the Uncleared total was updated to 0.
Hmm...this seems rare, but could happen during reconciliation.

<<Accounts>>

There may be times when you want to add an upcoming transaction, but the transaction hasn't cleared at your bank yet.
Thanks for the tip!

<<Accounts>>

In this case, you could add the transaction but leave the checkmark grey, uncleared, until a later date when the transaction has cleared at your bank.

<<Accounts>>

Close account: This is how you close the account you selected to view.
Ok; understood
I added 50 in the payment column
highlight: zoom_link
move_to: budget_name
move_to: add_account

<<Budget>>

In the top left, you will see multiple calendar icons. This option allows you to view multiple months at once (dependent on your browser page zooom level). Once you have used MyBudgetCoach for a few months, this can be a fast way to see a comparison in the amount of an expense compared to the budgeted amount.

<<Budget>>

Once you select the number of months you want to view, notice how the months in the top middle now have a 'purple' box around them. The purple box emphasizes the months you have selected for viewing. Click a different set of months to change the months you are viewing.
That's a nice feature!
Oh, I see that now

<<Budget>>

Below the row of month names are the Budget sections for the months selected. Each section has the month listed at the top.

<<Budget>>

Below the month header are a series of fields to give a summary of the total dollars and how they are allocated across the month.
Let's now move from the Account screen, to the Budget screen.
Got it; Accounts first, then Budget!

<<Budget>>

Please keep in mind that what happens in the Accounts is reflected in the numbers shown in the Budget. Each time you log in to MyBudgetCoach, plan on working on the account side first, and then once all transactions are categorized and cleared, move to the budget.
Let's do this!
That's a nice feature!

<<Budget>>

The first section is the 'To Budget' number. You can select this number and see options for moving the available dollars to a category in the table below.
OK! I am ready for the next section.

<<Budget>>

You have now completed the Budget Screen Summary! Our next step will be the Budget Table Summary.

<<Budget>>

To start, let's walk through each column in the Budget Table.
Ok; I am following along

<<Budget>>

The first column is the Category. These groups and individual categories are how you will organize your expenses. For example, if you paid for groceries at your local grocery store, that expense in the Accounts section would be categorized as 'Food'.
Tell me more...

<<Budget>>

The second column is 'Budgeted.' These fields are used to enter amounts which reduce the overall total from the 'To Budget' amount within the Budget Summary section.

<<Budget>>

When using MyBudgetCoach, you will budget all available dollars to specific categories in advance of spending. This methodology transforms your money management from 'reactive' looking at the end of the month and wondering what happened, to 'proactive' where you are creating a plan for how dollars will be used in advance of spending the money.

<<Budget>>

The third column is 'Spent.' This field holds the total of all transactions from the accounts that are categorized to that specific category. If you have three transactions for groceries that are categorized as 'Food', you can select the amount shown in the 'Spent' column in the 'Food' category row to see those three transactions on the account screen.

<<Budget>>

The last column is 'Balance.' The amount shown is a subtraction of the amounts in the Budgeted and Spent columns.

(Budgeted - Spent) = Balance
Ok; the total across all accounts
Tell me more...

<<Budget>>

Now that we have reviewed the columns of the Budget Table, let me walk through how to edit your Budget Table category groups and categories.
I have selected 'Collapse all'

<<Budget>>

To the right of the Category header are three dots. When you select this a series of options comes up. Select 'Collapse all.'
Categories are part of an overall Category Group. Got it!

<<Budget>>

You now see only rows with a grey shading. These are the 'Category Groups.' Within each Category Group are the Categories.
I have created the Category Group

<<Budget>>

Select the 'Add Group' button to add a new Category Group. Name the new group 'Fixed' and select Enter.
Fixed = Same amount of expense

<<Budget>>

The 'Fixed' Category Group will include Categories that have expenses which are generally the same amount month over month. For example, a rent or mortgage, a car payment, cell phone...
Fixed = Fund first!

<<Budget>>

When analyzing your budget, the 'Fixed' group of expenses can be viewed as necessities and where your money needs to go first. You have to make sure you have money available for your car payment prior the payment date.

<<Budget>>

Let's add another Category Group and call it 'Flexible.'
I have added a Category Group of Flexible
Flexible = Variable amounts

<<Budget>>

Flexible expenses are things required to live: groceries; gas for the car; clothing; but the same amount is not spent each month. These categories are those that you would want to analyze if you are looking to reduce spending resulting in left over income for savings or funding a future months' expenses.

<<Budget>>

Ok great! Now that we have Fixed and Flexible Category Groups, please navigate back to the main Category header and select the option of 'Expand All' under the three dots menu.
Ok; Great!

<<Budget>>

This now allows you to view the Categories within each of the Category Groups. We will now add and rename categories.

<<Budget>>

Navigate to the right of 'Fixed' to un-hide the down arrow and select 'Add category.' Name this newly created category 'Rent' or 'Mortgage,' whichever is applicable for you and select Enter.
I have added and named the category
I have added Groceries

<<Budget>>

Please move now to the Flexible Category Group. Please add a category for 'Groceries.'
I am ready to set-up my Budget Table.

<<Budget>>

Ok great! You have now successfully started to customize your Budget Table!
Negative = Take Action!

<<Budget>>

If Balance is negative, which can be identified by the red text, that means you have spent more than you budgeted. To address this, you need to add money to the Budgeted amount or shift money from another category with a positive Balance.

<<Budget>>

If Balance is positive, you have dollars left over not yet spent. These dollars could be used to fund an overage in another category.
Oh; I definitely want to avoid that!

<<Budget>>

If you don't have funds to either add to the Budgeted column or shift money from a category with a positive balance, then you are at risk for over spending your bank balance, or adding debt to your credit card balance, depending on which account the transaction came from.

Thanks for reminding me!

<<Budget>>

When we first met, I asked you an initial question for what brought you to MyBudgetCoach.
Yup; I now remember

<<Budget>>

You responded with the selection of: "My current budgeting system isn't bringing me closer to my financial wellness goals."
Ask away!

<<Budget>>

Now that I have walked through how to edit your Budget table, let me ask a question for if you want additional support creating your budget Categories.
Please Do!
Nope; I know what Categories I want

<<Budget>>

Would you like me to create a starting list of categories under each of the category groups of Fixed and Flexible?
Tell me more...

<<Budget>>

Good for you! Before you work on creating your budget, I would recommend adding two additional Category Groups: 1) Non-Monthly; 2) Goals.
Interesting idea

<<Budget>>

Non-Monthly can be used for expenses paid on a quarterly, twice a year, or annual basis. For example, Car Maintenance or Gifts for the yearly Holiday Season.

<<Budget>>

As your coach, I recommend you set aside an amount each month to these Categories. Overtime, the amount in your Balance will accumulate and be available for use when the expense does come up.

<<Budget>>

For the Goals Category Group, you could include luxury items/experiences that take time to save for, such as a New Laptop or a Vacation.
That sounds great!

<<Budget>>

The Categories in the Goals Category Group should also have dollars assigned each month. When that vacation comes up, you can leave your home stress free knowing you have a pot of money set aside to reduce stress spending money while on vacation!

That completes this Introductory conversation. I have enjoyed helping you through this tutorial and I am confident you have built a successful foundation for starting a new chapter in your personal finance journey and you are now a few steps closer toward financial wellness!
I can definitely do that!
I do enjoy a vacation!
I am all ears!

<<Budget>>

A few other organizational recommendations.
I willl add the due date!

<<Budget>>

Consider adding the day of the month your Fixed Categories are due to your Category Name. For example: Rent (1st). Then you can organize the Categories in day order to prioritize the use of your available money based on where you are in the month. Remember, fund the expenses due prior to the next time you receive income.
I will add the expected monthly total of the flexible expense(s) to the category name!

<<Budget>>

Also, consider adding the amount you expect to spend in a Flexible category in the Category Name. For example: Clothing - $100. Adding the amount you expect to spend will help you compare your actual spending to the amount you expect.
I hope that isn't me...but budgeting is a process that requires adjustments every month

<<Budget>>

If after your first full month of MyBudgetCoach use, your proposed amount is far off from the actual spent, you know you either need to change your spending behavior, or change the proposed amount for your budget.
I would rather know now and not at the end of this month!

<<Budget>>

Adding an amount to each Flexible Category Name creates the ability for you to total up your proposed amounts across your Categories and compare that to your Income - Fixed Expenses - Flexible Expenses. If the result is negative, you know it is highly unlikely you will have savings available at the end of each month.
Oh, great idea!

<<Budget>>

You can also add the total of your Categories to the name of your Category Group. This is a quick way of looking at your overall spending on any one day of the month compared to the total anticipated, without analyzing each Category individually.
A snap-shot of how I am doing in the month would be very helpful!

<<Budget>>

For example, if you are half-way through the month, but have spent 75% of your Flexible total proposed amount, you should analyze further what adjustments need to be made for the second half of the month to either remain within the proposed amount, or find more dollars to increase the Balance available.

<<Budget>>

Finally, make the budget unique by adding some emojis to your Category and Category Group Names!

Make it fun and personalized to you so when you log-in to MyBudgetCoach, you have a connection to your customized budget!
Good to know!
You can select 'Reset Coach' in the 'Manage Coach' menu to the left and navigate back through from the beginning of the tutorial to any section you want to cover again.
Thanks for your direct contact information!

If while using the system, you have a question that you come across, feel free to send me an email at nick@personalwealthadventures.com. Please identify yourself as a MyBudgetCoach user in the subject line and include your first and last name in the message. I will review the message and if I can, I will provide an answer back via email, free of charge.
If after reviewing your inquiry I determine it would be best to have a conversation, I will recommend you schedule a one-hour session with me through the MyBudgetCoach platform.
Thanks for the heads up!

To pay for a one-on-one session, I will send you an invoice via the Square platform to your email you provided when you booked the call. I ask that payment is completed prior to the scheduled session.
Bye for now Nick, and thanks for all your help!
KUDOS on taking action and completing this tutorial of the MyBudgetCoach software. Contact me if you have any questions in the future and have a great rest of your day!

I cleared the transaction

Here is a good question to ask yourself each time you are entering amounts into your Budgeted column for all your categories, essentially giving all of your dollars a job, so that the 'To Budget' purple number = 0.

What do these dollars need to do prior to getting my next paycheck?

If you select the number in the Balance column, you will see an option for 'Move category.' Once selected, you can enter an amount and then select the category to move that money to. This can be helpful when moving money from an overfunded category to an underfunded category. The available dollars can be used however you would like!
Positive = Money Available!
This helps address the flexibility in my spending!

<<Budget>>

Think of MyBudgetCoach as creating a series of digital envelopes to store your money. Each envelope has a specific purpose and creates intentionality in your cash flow management.
Digital envelopes I can update at any time and customize for my lifestyle. Awesome!
I am ready to get started!

Within MyBudgetCoach you have three options for how you want to add transactions to your accounts.

Option 1: Add Individual Transactions
Option 2: Bulk Import
Option 3: Direct import

For this conversation, we are going to walk through Option 1, adding individual transactions.
Good to know!

PHASE 2

What kind of device?

If using a tablet, somethings are different (tap versus hover; double click versus single click...). In the bottom right window of an open conversation, there are three vertical dots. This gives you the option to:

1) Give Feedback
2) Reset This Conversation
3) End This Conversation
I will keep this in mind

You can tell which conversation you are currently working through by reviewing the open conversations on the left hand menu and determining which scenario is applicable.

Scenario 1: The conversation that is greyed out and has the words 'In progress...' below the conversation title is the conversation you are currently working through.
Scenario 2: A conversation that is a white box and has the words 'Continue conversation...' below the conversation title is a conversation you have started, but not completed.

You have the ability to select a conversation to complete under the option 'Start a New Conversation.' Feel free to review these later, but for now, let's complete this conversation prior to starting a new one.

Thanks for your answer! Let's add one more account to capture your total expenses.

Thanks for your answer! Let's now add the credit card account that is used the most often of your remaining accounts.

<<Accounts>>

How many transactions per week occur on your remaining credit card account?
Oh right, understood

<<Accounts>>

As you continue to use MyBudgetCoach, please keep in mind each account requires reconciliation, a few times a week, and categorizing of transactions.

When in your Budget, the 'To Budget' number is critical to monitor. If it is positive, you have dollars left that need a job in the current month. If it is negative, you over budgeted, and need to take money back. If it is 0, you have successfully balanced your budget. Adding cc debt
Yes; how do I resolve this?

Sometimes expenses come up and you don't have the money for them so you use a credit card. Now I'm telling you to cover your overspending but there are no available funds to cover it (and you already knew that).

The reality of the situation is that you added debt on your credit card. Rather than having groceries debt and car repairs debt overspent in categories, it's much easier if all the debt is in one place, in this case the credit card payment category.

LONG TERM As applicable, offer a 'help' section that has a link to a support guide article for how to use that section. YNAB blogs are great, but you have to sift through everything. If someone could hover over a section of the software and then be able to select a link that brought them to the troubleshooting blog article, that would be amazing! Users would quickly get to the article they need in less than 5 seconds versus sifting through and maybe never finding it.

If the client links a Savings Account - IMPORTANT - immediately have Client create a Category Group = Savings and add a Category for Savings - Even if they want to use it long-term, don't allow Client to accidentally budget the dollars from Savings into the main categories - they get frustrated after month 1 that their savings went down and some forget to transfer money in between accounts

Nick's Coach Persona (Nick version 1):
DETAILED Hand holding Your grandmother could do this Methodical Optimize Have 20-30 minutes
Not for people who are self-sufficient and quick starters; If someone wants to get up and running in 5 minutes, pick a different coach. I like the detail and I believe it adds value and transparency.
Long-term I could build a persona version of me that is 'faster' and could ask a question upfront something like: Welcome, how much time do you have? 5 minutes or less; 10 minutes, 20 minutes or more.

COMPLEX PAIN POINTS:
  • Linking Savings and accidentally budgeting dollars into monthly catergories
  • Reconciliation - some days it is easy - some days it is hard
  • Targets - People kind of get them but when you use non-Needed for Spending, Clients are frustrated with the behavior of the tool. Easily could prompt Client to pick target that makes sense based on Category name or grouping of category (recurring weekly or monthly expense)?
  • When you set-up targets, have the person feelokto not full the fund target. I have had Clients that make plenty of money and have plenty of money so funding targets fully at the start of the month for the whole month is just as easy as transferring their total targets to their 'Operating Account' from their 'Inflow Account.'
  • I have other Clients that it is a HUGE stresser to not fund the target. Avatar should compare automatically Money in the Ready to Assign compared to the total of targets and have encouraging words or suggestions when getting to targets and not much money left - This will be hard to do, but I think the avatar knowing how much money is available and helping ask things like, I see you are getting low on your money available - Have you covered your essentials? I don't see you funded money in Groceries or Gas for Car. Is that something you want to prioritize?
  • Can the system watch what the person is doing and then change the response based on the level of ready to assign left? For example, if the system knows the standard 15-20 categories everyone has (groceries, rent/mortgage, utilities....) could it then help the user to have the avatar give reminders on when things are not funded enough?
  • Something along the lines of:I see you have budgeted down to $0. Great job! However, you have 20 days remaining in the month and I see you only funded $100 for Groceries. Please confirm that is an accurate amount. (RANDOM THOUGHTS)
  • Interest on credit cards - YNAB recommends to use a different category. This is weird for people to conceptualize. Especially those that are paying just minimum payments. The concept is that Interest is a separate expense. The minimum payment includes interest. Avatar should seek out an Interest transaction and then have the person categorize as interest to ensure handled correctly. Since it is a credit card outflow, when the user funds the interest, that will add to the payment amount. If you also assign dollars for the minimum payment, now you are paying more principal since the minimum payment generally includes the interest that may accrue so acclerating debt pay off versus just paying the minimum. In YNAB, the calculation of paying off a balance is assuming that no interest is added, because they expect users to add a different Interest category. The target that can be set with a pay-off date just uses the current balance. That amount may be less than the minimum payment required (although unlikely) because interest is accounted for separately in YNAB, where as the minimum payment already has the interest baked in.
  • After a full month 1 - they log in and the system prompts for a Report overview - not helpful until you have enough data to show something
  • System has to thread the line between 'judging' and 'leading.' Each person is different and those who pay for a coach are generally open-minded and seeking the feedback so very ratrely do they view as 'judging.' However, a user who hasn't paid for a coach may feel the system is 'judging' their choices. It would be good to have a language expert make sure that the terminology isn't harsh or too judgemental of the person's behavior, while still leveraging the fact they did something wrong and/or need help and/or using the system it wasn't intended for.
  • If the Cleared Credit Card balance does not equal, or is $X higher, then the Credit Card payment available, have the avatar could ask the question - do you plan to pay the balance in full? If yes, then you need to Assign dollars to the Credit Card category for the difference between your total balance and your available payment (month 1 of use of tool ONLY). If the answer is no, launch them to the module to select a pay-off date.
  • When a user makes a transfer to a separate account manually by Adding a Transaction, have the Avatar pop-up reminding them the money should be moved in 'reality' as well. It is better to move the money in reality and then have MyBudgetCoach catch up with the movement later on. Since both accounts are linked in YNAB, moving money from Checking to Savings doesn't add to Ready to Assign. All the dollars were in one big pot so although moving dollars from savings to checking, MyBudgetCoach doesn't care.
  • If the working balance of an account does not equal the bank, have the Avatar walk through the reconciliation process. Show running balance, pick a date and verify it is correct, continue moving closer and closer to the present balance and research your financial institution transactions. Maybe have a separate set of fields that come up so the user can verify which balance / transaction matches their financial institution. This would facilitate a review of the transactions prior to reconciliation. It can be difficult in current YNAB because everything is already cleared, so there isn't a way to differentiate 'researched' versus 'not researched' transactions when completing reconciliation.
  • Venmo - if a user has a transaction with Venmo, Avatar pops up and explains Venmo should be used as a pass through. Venmo outflows are shown in YNAB from the appropriate account. Just needs to be categorized, which can be difficult to remember which transaction was for what. Not using the Venmo balance means Client isn't at risk of spending using a Venmo balance and then forgetting the transaction all together.
  • Current YNAB it is easy to Assign dollars and think you have added a target. It isn't unless you notice the very subtle 'Funded' prior to the spent or assigned information, or you move to the next month with no dollars assigned or spending occurring, that then it is clear which categories don't have targets.
  • Any other specific situational triggers.
  • Build a repository for Bank name and the calculation of the current balance (whether including or excluding pending transactions)

Actual Specific:
  • When setting up a CC, Make sure to add the Category of Debt Group, so it isn't a starting balance that is automatically reducing the Ready to Assign for debt.

The following are step-by-step instructions for how to add a Filter. I recommend you complete these steps along with my explanation.
Select Category: There are options at the top of the new pop-up window. Under those, is the list of your categories which you can select from.

Once a category is selected, you can select 'Apply' and those will be the only transactions you see. 

Select a Category and select 'Apply.'
A new box has now shown up above the transaction table. This is how you can know which filters have been added for the transactions you are viewing.
Each time a new filter is added, the transaction list will automatically change to match the criteria selected.

Remove Filter: There are
two ways to remove the filter: 1) You can select the 'x' in each of the newly added boxes above the transaction table; or 2) You can select the 'Unsaved filter' on the right side of the screen, and then select Clear all conditions.

Balance: As we reviewed earlier, if you select the 'Show running balance' option, this column appears and the balance after each transaction is shown.
Date: The date of the transaction.

Square Box to the Left of Column Headings: 
Allows you to select all transactions being shown and unselect transactions that are selected.

Payee: This is the vendor you purchased the item from. Overtime, MyBudgetCoach will remember the Payee and the Category you select. Long-term, the system will propose a category, versus having to select the category for every transaction that is routine, such as your local grocery store.
Notes: Section that allows you to make quick notes about the transaction for long-term reference.

Category: The available options are set-up within the Budget. As you type in the box, the list of your categories filters down for ease of selecting your chosen category. If you need to add a category, add it to the Budget and then come back to the Account screen to select the appropriate category.

Payment: Outflow for the bank account. The amount of the expense. For the bank account, a 'Payment' amount reduces the positive balance. For a credit card, a 'Payment' amount increases the negative balance.
Deposit: Inflow for the bank account. The amount of income. For the bank account, a 'Deposit' amount increases the positive balance. For a credit card, a 'Deposit' decreases the negative balance.

BREAK - This is rare for 'YNAB Coaches.' Many of them have packages where you meet weekly or once every two weeks. They feel like they are adding value. I disagree. To start, let's walk through each column in the Budget Table.
Ok; I am following along

<<Budget>>

The first column is the Category. These groups and individual categories are how you will organize your expenses. For example, if you paid for groceries at your local grocery store, that expense in the Accounts section would be categorized as 'Food'.
Tell me more...

<<Budget>>

The second column is 'Budgeted.' These fields are used to enter amounts which reduce the overall total from the 'To Budget' amount within the Budget Summary section.

<<Budget>>

When using MyBudgetCoach, you will assign all available dollars to specific categories in advance of spending. This methodology transforms your money management from 'reactive' looking at the end of the month and wondering what happened, to 'proactive' where you are creating a plan for how dollars will be used in advance of spending the money.

<<Budget>>

The third column is 'Spent.' This field holds the total of all transactions from the accounts that are categorized to that specific category. If you have three transactions for groceries that are categorized as 'Food', you can select the amount shown in the 'Spent' column in the 'Food' category row to see those three transactions on the account screen.

<<Budget>>

The last column is 'Balance.' The amount shown is a subtraction of the amounts in the Budgeted and Spent columns.

(Budgeted - Spent) = Balance

MyBudgetCoach uses machine learning, so as you continue to use the system, the system will automatically apply proposed categories to new transactions and the manual steps to categorize transactions will lessen over time.

To increase your security, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with a third party service, SimpleFIN, to link your accounts. SimpleFIN uses a well-established connection software called 'MX' to connect your bank account financial institutions to SimpleFIN.

<<Accounts>>

To connect SimpleFIN to MyBudgetCoach, there is a one-time code produced by SimpleFIN to enter into MyBudgetCoach. The accounts you link in SimpleFIN will then become available to add in MyBudgetCoach for Direct Import.

<<Accounts>>

Please note SimpleFIN does have a small additional fee: $1.50 per month, or $15 per year. This is charged in addition to your MyBudgetCoach subscription and is paid through SimpleFIN, not within MyBudgetCoach.
